resources.string: Cavities (or Caries) occur as a result of tooth decay.\n\nTooth decay is the destruction of the tooth structure. Tooth decay can affect both the enamel and the dentin.
Oralbalance©\n\nA long lasting lubricant that relieves, soothes and protects dry mouth tissues against dry discomfort, minor irritations, and burning sensations.
Regular Water\n\nKeep a water bottle handy and take sips frequently.
Keep a water bottle handy and take sips frequently. It\'s also important to stay away from acidic beverages, such as orange juice, soda and any drink that contains citric or phosphoric acid.
Sugar-Free Sweets\n\nSuck on sugar-free hard candies to stimulate the flow of saliva.
Suck on sugar-free hard candies to stimulate the flow of saliva.

● Prolonging the action of BioXtra toothpaste 
● Supplementing saliva's natural protective mechanisms 
● Maintaining a pH which helps prevent plaque formation 
● Refreshing and moistening the mouth
Oralbalance© long lasting lubricant relieves, soothes and protects dry mouth tissues against dry discomfort, minor irritations, and burning sensations.
Understanding Problems associated with Dry Mouth

● Dry mouth is not a normal part of aging.

● Many common medications reduce the production of saliva.

● Many of the persons you care for are taking these medications and will suffer from dry mouth.

● Dry mouth can increase risk of dental cavities, gum disease and infection.

● Dry mouth can also make it hard to eat, swallow, taste, speak and can cause dentures not to fit properly.

● Bleeding Gums

● Red, swollen, or tender gums

● Persistent bad breath

● Bad taste in the mouth

● Receding gums

● Formation of deep pockets

● Loose or shifting teeth

► Illnesses may affect the condition of the gums.

► Medications can affect oral health.

► Bad habits such as smoking, make it harder for gum tissue to repair itself.

► Poor oral hygiene habits.

► Family history of dental disease.

The following are some user friendly hygiene aids that can be of help in cases where there are dexterity issues.
Electric toothbrushes have larger handles that can be gripped more easily by persons with physical impairments.\n\nThey are also easier for caregivers to use when cleaning someone else’s teeth.

The Collis Curve toothbrush is designed with three rows of bristles that can clean the front, back, and top surfaces of teeth at the same time.\n\nThis brush may be easier for caregivers to use and also for older persons that have limited movement in their fingers and hands.

Flossing can be difficult to do even for those of us that don’t have any physical or cognitive impairments.

For more control you could try holders that come with long handles.

This dental aid can be very helpful for caregivers.

Inter Dental-brushes are little toothbrushes and come in a variety of sizes.

These are especially good when there are spaces between teeth.

Piksters are the interdental brushes we recommend as they have a longer handle than other varieties.
Two or three of these on a toothbrush can help those with manual Dexterity issues.
Ideal as, like the collis curve, you can clean font back and top of teeth at the same time.

Plaque is the most common and serious dental health issue.

It is a soft and sticky film of bacteria from food and sweets.

Hardened plaque is called calculus and holds bacteria in the mouth. It causes damage to the gums and bone that supports the teeth.
It is plaque, not aging, that causes tooth loss!
The mouth is a mirror of health and disease
Importance of Dental Health to Overall Health and Well-Being

► Dental health is important because dental disease and mouth problems are common in the nursing home and homebound population.\n\n►You have probably noticed that many of the persons you care for have problems with their mouths.

The mouth has been called a mirror of health and disease because there you’ll find signs of:

► Systemic diseases

► Nutritional deficiencies

Oral health and general health should not be thought of as being separate.

Common Conditions seen in many patients:

► Cardiovascular disease
► Diabetes
► Malnutrition
► Stroke
► Pneumonia

Poor oral health can make these medical problems worse because of the increased bacteria in the mouth that spread to other systems of the body.

► Poor self-esteem - Decreased social interaction

► Problems with eating, sleeping or speech

► Mouth pain

The most common mouth problems in patients in long-term care are:

► Gum Disease

► Dental Cavities

► Sores in the Mouth

► Ill-fitting Dentures

► Little Saliva

Dentures must be cleaned at least once daily.

Use a denture brush or soft toothbrush and rub off plaque and food particles on teeth including the outside and inside of denture under running water.

Put a towel in the sink to protect dentures from breaking if they fall accidentally or use a plastic bowl.

Denture cleaning tablets can be used but only AFTER cleaning with washing up liquid and warm (hand hot) water.

All denture paste or powder should be removed from the denture each day before applying new denture paste or powder.

Dentures, whether full or partial should not be worn all day.

Leave dentures out at least 6 hours per day to allow the gums to breathe - This is usually overnight.

Wearing dentures constantly can irritate the gums and harbour bacteria.

Dentures that fit poorly can also irritate gums.

The foam mouth prop was designed for caregivers to use to help keep the mouth open among older persons with cognitive impairment.

The unique design of the head and handle give greater safety, control, and comfort.

You can also make a mouth prop by wrapping gauze to a cushion at the end of a tongue depressor.

It is vital that EXTRA care is taken if using a ‘home made’ prop as the gauze can come loose and could be swallowed.

Are any Teeth or Parts Missing?
Is there a crack or a clean break?
Before calling Dental Tech Group, please check the following information so that we can make the necessary arrangements for a replacement denture.

1. Is it an upper or a lower denture? 
2. Is it a full or a partial Denture? 
3. How long since they lost the Denture? 
4. Has the patient got a denture in the opposing arch or are they without teeth? 
 5. Is the patient capable of complying with the treatment involved in fitting a new denture? i.e. 4 visits.
Does the resident have a medical card?
Has the resident had a denture made under the medical card scheme in the last 5 years?
We will provide the replacement denture privately.
Please Call Dental Tech Group on 01 455 1866 with the residents Name and above details

The denture will be covered by the medical card scheme. We need to send for approval from the HSE for the denture and this can take up to 6 weeks. Treatment cannot start until the approval is received. Treatment will then take six weeks to complete.
Before calling Dental Tech Group, please check the following information so that we can make an assessment of need and urgency.
1. Is the patient capable of expressing/identifying the source of their pain?
2. Has the GP been able to identify the source of the pain?
3. Was the patient kept awake with the pain or becoming agitated?
4. Do you need to give pain killers? If yes, what have you given and are they effective?
5. Does the patient have a loose tooth causing discomfort/pain?
6. Is there soreness being caused by a denture?
9. Is there a sensitive/sharp or broken tooth?
Please call Dental Tech Group on (01)455 1866 and we will help assess if an emergancy call out is needed

The best way to help reduce the build-up of bacteria and staining is by having a strict daily caring and cleaning routine.\n\nThe following 5 steps will help you take good care of your dentures (#8230)

Soaking them in a good denture disinfectant can kill 99% percent of denture germs.

We recommend using Nitradine tablets for soaking as it only takes 15 minutes.

Most denture disinfectants have a mild bleaching agent which overtime can change the colour of your dentures so check your denture cleaner first to make sure it will disinfect them in a short time rather than leaving them overnight.

BUT PLEASE CLEAN THEM FIRST.

Brush your dentures with a regular soft-bristled brush or dish brush, use warm water and some washing up liquid, yes washing up liquid.

Toothpaste is an abrasive material designed to work best on the enamel of your teeth so toothpaste can actually damage the surface of your dentures.

As dentures are a type of plastic they are best cleaned with washing up liquid or soap.

Remember to always give your mouth a good rinse when you take out your dentures and then to massage your gums with a washcloth or a soft toothbrush.\n\nUse a pea sized amount of toothpaste on the brush and gently rub around the inside of your cheeks, gums and tongue to stimulate them and help promote a healthy mouth.

You should love your denture, it is part of you and it is fragile, make sure you handle them carefully.\n\nWash over a plastic bowl full of water or a folded towel so as to reduce the risk of dropping them in the sink or on the floor.

If your denture is not fitting properly, functioning well or it just doesn’t look great on you, don’t hesitate calling Dental Tech Group (www.dentaltech.ie) to book in for your Free Denture consultation with one of our experienced treatment plan coordinators.
A mild inflammation and redness of the oralmucous membrane that occurs beneath a denture.
Pain is usually not a symptom of the disease

It is important to notice the early signs of oral cancer.

● Swellings

● Red or white patches

● Sores

● Numbness or lumps anywhere
